The date marks the most recent update on the death toll and missing persons, reflecting ongoing humanitarian efforts and emergency response.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states, with the death toll continuing to rise.
The state of Veracruz reported 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and one in Queretaro.
Another 65 people are still missing, with significant numbers unaccounted for in Hidalgo (43), Veracruz (18), and Puebla (4).
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist affected areas, including air drops of food and clean water.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
Approximately 100,000 homes have been affected, with some structures near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply in the affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
Governors and federal authorities are coordinating emergency response efforts across five states.
The government has acknowledged that there were no clear meteorological warnings indicating the extreme rainfall, raising questions about early warning systems and disaster preparedness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have caused severe flooding in five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 confirmed deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas include Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with significant numbers of homes damaged or destroyed. The Mexican military—Army, Air Force, and National Guard—has deployed thousands of personnel to deliver food, clean water, and humanitarian aid, especially in areas blocked by landslides. Despite extensive damage, over 80% of electricity has been restored through efforts by nearly 400 repair workers. The government acknowledged that there were no early meteorological warnings for such extreme rainfall, raising concerns about the effectiveness of disaster preparedness and early warning systems in Mexico.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
